channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Gaza Prepares to Launch Mass Polio Vaccination Campaign
item.description: The first confirmed case of polio in the enclave in 25 years prompted UNICEF to send 1.2 million doses of the vaccine to Gaza, but distributing them during a war is expected to be challenging.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Telegram Turmoil Threatens Chronicle of Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: The detention of Telegram’s founder has highlighted the messaging app’s outsized status in Europe’s deadliest war since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, the founder and chief executive of Telegram, in San Francisco in 2014.

item.title: Italy Opens Investigation Into Captain of Sunken Yacht’s Conduct
item.description: The investigation does not necessarily imply that formal charges will follow against the captain, James Cutfield.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: The Bayesian sank a week ago off the coast of Sicily, killing seven of the 22 people on board.

item.title: Chinese Military Plane Breaches Japanese Airspace, a First
item.description: The territorial violation by China is the latest in a series of events amplifying tensions between Beijing and Japan.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Chen Jimin/China News Service, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Y-9 aircraft at an airshow in Zhuhai, China, in 2022, in a photo released by Chinese state media.

item.title: At Least 38 Killed in Attacks in Southwestern Pakistan
item.description: At least 38 people have been killed in several assaults across Baluchistan Province since Sunday in what appears to be part of a campaign by armed separatists in the region.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: A vehicle on Monday that was said to have been set on fire by gunmen in the Pakistani province of Baluchistan.

item.title: China to Hold Live-Fire Drills Near War-Torn Myanmar’s
item.description: Beijing likely wants to signal to Myanmar’s junta leaders that they should return to peace talks and de-escalate the conflict, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: People’s Liberation Army cadets in Qingdao, China, earlier this year.

item.title: No Evidence that Maduro Won, Says Top Venezuelan Election Official
item.description: In an interview with The New York Times, an electoral council official expressed grave doubts about claims to victory by the authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Juan Carlos Delpino, a member of Venezuela’s National Electoral Council, said the body “failed the country” in proclaiming President Nicolás Maduro the victor in elections last month.

item.title: Russia Pounds Ukraine With ‘One of the Largest Strikes’ of the War
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Taking shelter in a subway station in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday. Russia struck regions across the country.

item.title: Fox Hunters in the U.K. Want Protected Status Under Discrimination Law
item.description: A lobbying group is preparing a bid to define hunting with animals as a protected belief. Many experts have questions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Warwickshire Hunt in February 2023, in Warwickshire, England. Since fox hunting with packs of dogs was banned in 2005, many hunts use trail hunting, where dogs follow a scent trail of fox urine instead of a live animal.

item.title: A Fire in East London Recalls Deadly Grenfell Cladding Scandal
item.description: More than 80 people were evacuated in the early hours of Monday from a building that had used similar insulation.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Smoke continued to rise on Monday from an apartment building in East London after an early morning fire broke out.

item.title: German Prosecutor Says Islamic State Terrorist Link Is Suspected in Festival Stabbings
item.description: The police say they have arrested a man they believe killed three people and wounded eight others at a festival in the town of Solingen, in western Germany.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Police officers late Saturday with a suspect in the killings at a festival in Solingen, Germany.

item.title: Questions for Investigators as Italy Tries to Unravel the Yacht’s Sinking
item.description: The investigators searching for answers about the shipwreck, leaving seven dead, face questions about extreme weather and possible human error or problems with the yacht itself.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Divers conducting the search for victims near Palermo, Italy, on Friday.

item.title: Is Taiwan Ready for War With China? A Show Has People Asking.
item.description: Some think the drama, “Zero Day,” helps Taiwan confront an increasingly plausible scenario. Others say the show is alarmist and a tool of the government.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the film crew for the drama series “Zero Day” preparing for a protest scene to be shot on location in front of the presidential palace on Saturday in Taipei, Taiwan.

item.title: War Fuels Poetry Boom in Ukraine
item.description: With verses that capture the raw emotions of the war and resonate deeply with the population, Ukrainian poets have emerged as some of the country’s most influential voices.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An open-mic poetry reading for beginners at a bookstore in July in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches a Large-Scale Attack
item.description: Plus, badminton instead of sex.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
item.media:description: A building damaged by a Russian missile strike on a village in the Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: Dam Collapse Devastates Communities in Eastern Sudan
item.description: The Arba’at dam fell apart after days of heavy rain, killing villagers and flooding communities.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Trucks were damaged after the deadly collapse of the Arba’at dam on Sunday.

item.title: How Pavel Durov, Telegram’s Founder, Went From Russia’s Mark Zuckerberg to Wanted Man
item.description: Pavel Durov’s anti-establishment streak helped him create one of the world’s biggest online platforms, which emphasizes free speech. It also put a target on his back.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, in 2014. “Privacy, ultimately, is more important than our fear of bad things happening, like terrorism,” he posted in 2015.

item.title: Hungry for Clean Energy, Facebook Looks to a New Type of Geothermal
item.description: As electricity demand from data centers soars, Meta and Google are looking at a novel solution: harnessing clean heat far below Earth’s surface.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Fervo Energy geothermal site near Milford, Utah, last year. Meta has announced a similar project with a Sage Geosystems in Texas.

item.title: Polio Vaccines Arrive in Gaza, but Distributing Them Is the Next Challenge
item.description: UNICEF is pushing for a pause in the fighting to allow health workers to get two doses to every child, after Gaza recorded its first polio case in 25 years.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Children walking near garbage and raw sewage at a camp for displaced Palestinians in Deir al Balah in central Gaza this month.

item.title: Hong Kong Defends Sex Ed Advice That Includes Playing Badminton
item.description: Top officials in the Chinese territory have defended new sex education guidance that critics call regressive. Young people are amused.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Wang and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Jeffrey Greenberg/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Playing badminton in Hong Kong.

item.title: Dismantling the Ship That Drilled for the Ocean’s Deepest Secrets
item.description: The JOIDES Resolution, which for decades was key to advancing the understanding of the Earth and its innards, concluded what could be its final scientific expedition.
item.dc:creator: Maya Wei-Haas
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the International Ocean Discovery Program welcomed the arrival of the JOIDES Resolution in Amsterdam on Aug. 2 for its final berth.

item.title: Getting to Know Kenya Through a Local Hiking Club
item.description: The author sought an authentic experience, and found it in Lets Drift, “an exuberant Kenyan-centered enterprise” of people living in and near Nairobi.
item.dc:creator: Rolf Potts

item.title: Israel Averts All-Out War With Hezbollah, but Regional Conflicts Grind On
item.description: Relief that an eruption of violence across the border between Israel and Lebanon has been contained is tempered by a lack of progress in ending the fighting in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an airstrike on Zibqin in southern Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Will Continue in Cairo, Officials Say
item.description: Four days of high-level meetings failed to achieve a breakthrough, but people briefed on the talks said discussions on technical issues would take place in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A building in northern Israel damaged during a Hezbollah attack.

item.title: Iceland Ice Wall Collapse: 1 Tourist Is Dead and 1 Is Injured
item.description: Rescuers on Monday called off a search for what they initially believed were two other trapped tourists after it became clear that all the visitors were accounted for.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: STOD2/ Vilhelm Gunnarsson, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue teams at the scene of an ice cave collapse at the Breidamerkurjokull glacier in southeastern Iceland on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Exchange Major Attacks
item.description: Plus, DMZ honey.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli airstrike on the Lebanese side of the border yesterday.

item.title: In a Region on Edge, Israel and Hezbollah Launch Major Attacks on Each Other
item.description: The escalating strikes across the Israel-Lebanon border fueled fears of a bigger conflagration, but both sides signaled that they were de-escalating, for now.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Flames and smoke rising over southern Lebanon after Israeli airstrikes against Hezbollah targets, on Sunday.

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Two Bus Crashes in Pakistan
item.description: One of the accidents killed 12 people who were returning from a religious pilgrimage to Iraq, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: The area where a bus fell into a ravine near Kahuta, Pakistan, on Sunday.

item.title: Suspect Arrested in French Synagogue Blast
item.description: Antiterrorism prosecutors said officers had taken a man into custody in connection with a blast outside a synagogue in the southern French resort of La Grande Motte.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Investigators in La Grande Motte, France, near where the explosions took place on Saturday. Officials have called it a terrorist act.

item.title: After Attacks, Israel and Hezbollah Swiftly Move to Talk of Containment
item.description: Hezbollah’s long-dreaded retaliation for the killing of a senior commander appeared to be over before it began. But analysts said tensions could yet escalate further.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: An Israeli Air Force fighter jet ejecting flares as it intercepts a drone launched from Lebanon, over the border area with southern Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: How the Latest Israel-Hezbollah Strikes Unfolded
item.description: Israel and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah carried out some of their heaviest cross-border attacks in months on Sunday morning.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A drone intercepted by the Israeli military over northern Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Arrest of Telegram’s Pavel Durov Becomes Free Speech Flashpoint
item.description: Pavel Durov, the founder of the app, which has more than 900 million users, was taken into custody by the French authorities.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, who founded the online communications platform Telegram, shown in 2014 in San Francisco.

item.title: Reuters Safety Adviser Killed and 2 Journalists Injured in Strike on Ukraine Hotel
item.description: Reuters said that a safety adviser working with the journalists was killed, and that two other members of its team were wounded after a hotel in eastern Ukraine was hit in a strike on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency workers at the site of a damaged hotel on Sunday in Kramatorsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Inside Israel’s Hunt for the Leader of Hamas, Yahya Sinwar
item.description: Yahya Sinwar’s ability to evade capture or death has denied Israel a military success in a war that began after he planned the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Before the war between Israel and Hamas, Yahya Sinwar was a towering presence in Gaza.

item.title: Timeline of Recent Tensions in the Middle East
item.description: Tensions in the region had been high for weeks before Israel and Hezbollah began more intense cross-border attacks early Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Anjana Sankar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathering in Tehran after the assassination of the Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in July.

item.title: U.S. Moves Naval Forces Closer to Israel
item.description: American officials are sending a signal to Iran and its allies, in the form of two aircraft carrier groups and a guided-missile submarine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Aaron Haro Gonzalez/U.S. Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A U.S. fighter jet taking off from the Theodore Roosevelt aircraft carrier when it was in the East Sea a few months ago. It is now in or near the Gulf of Oman, the Pentagon said.

item.title: In France, Amine Kessaci Strives to Empower Multicultural Areas
item.description: As a teenager, Amine Kessaci confronted Emmanuel Macron, founded an environmental group and lost a brother to drug violence. At 20, he almost won a National Assembly seat.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ambition of Amine Kessaci, the son of Algerian immigrants, speaks to a changing France. He is representative of citizens from immigrant backgrounds who are agitating to be heard and included.

item.title: Explosions Outside a France Synagogue Were a Terrorist Attack, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Politicians quickly condemned the attack, at a time when antisemitic incidents have been on the rise in France. A suspect has been arrested in the case.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Law enforcement officials near a building that was damaged in the attack on the synagogue in Le Grande Motte, France, on Saturday.

item.title: New Arrest Made in Knife Attack That Left 3 Dead in Germany
item.description: The authorities announced the end of a manhunt, nearly a day after the attack, which happened Friday night at a festival in the city of Solingen.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and John Yoon
item.media:description: Special forces officers inside a building in Solingen, Germany, on Saturday after a stabbing attack that killed three people.

item.title: Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Italy Yacht Sinking
item.description: A prosecutor involved in the inquiry into the sinking said it was “plausible” that crimes were committed during the accident.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: Rescue personnel transporting a bag believed to hold the body of Hannah Lynch, the daughter of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, on Friday off Porticello, Sicily.

item.title: Zelensky Independence Day Speech Praises Ukraine’s Russia Offensive
item.description: Although the cross-border offensive carries risks, it also paid dividends on Saturday with the first prisoner swap with Russia in several months.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kyiv’s Independence Square commemorated fallen fighters during Independence Day celebrations on Saturday.

item.title: Bus Accident in Nepal Kills at Least 27
item.description: Nepal, a poor and mountainous country, has long struggled with road safety.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Rescue workers raising an injured passenger to safety in Nepal, where on Friday a bus carrying tourists from India went off the road and fell into a river at the bottom of a gorge.

item.title: Hamas Agrees to Meet With Mediators in Cairo Ahead of Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: Fighting has raged in Gaza even as the United States, Qatar and Egypt have pushed for a deal, with Israeli strikes overnight killing dozens, according to health officials in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A car buried in rubble after an Israeli airstrike in Nuseirat, in central Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Out of Season
item.description: Summer’s coming to a close soon. You’re still, to some extent, in control of how you spend the time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: With Freight Off the Rails, Rare Open Tracks for Passenger Trains
item.description: The brief lockout of freight railway workers gave Via Rail Canada trains a temporary reprieve from their second-class status.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Unlike Amtrak, Via Rail’s trains don’t have priority over freight.

item.title: South Korean Beekeepers Find Meaning Working Near the DMZ
item.description: The heavily fortified area separating North and South Korea is home to a biodiverse landscape and is a place of deep meaning for nearby farmers whose bees can fly freely through it.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Youmi Kim and Jun Michael Park
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times

item.title: Not Only for Killing: Drones Are Now Detecting Land Mines in Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine is a beta test for embedding artificial intelligence and other new technologies in drones and robots to find deadly land mines, saving lives and allowing military forces to advance more quickly.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An agricultural drone carrying a magnetic sensor to help survey land for mines last year during a demonstration in the Zhytomyr region of Ukraine.

item.title: Mexico’s President Bet Big on Oil. His Successor Will Be Stuck With the Tab.
item.description: Mexico’s next leader, Claudia Sheinbaum, is a climate scientist who has signaled a clean energy pivot. But a huge wager on fossil fuels by her political mentor stands in her way.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:description: The Olmeca oil refinery belonging to Pemex, the state-controlled oil company, in Paraiso, Mexico.

item.title: In Lebanese Refugee Community, People See Hope in Hamas
item.description: In Ein al-Hilweh, Lebanon, long mired in poverty and despair, Hamas recruitment is up and the downtrodden air has given way to defiance and celebration.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of the Qassam Brigades spokesman, Abu Ubaida, on the right in this mural in Bourj al-Barajne, are a common sight in Palestinian refugee communities in Lebanon.

item.title: Bus in Cambodia Is a Mobile Museum of Khmer Rouge Crimes
item.description: Most people in Cambodia are under 30, born long after the horrific rule of the Khmer Rouge. A bus is touring the country to make sure it’s not forgotten.
item.dc:creator: Anton L. Delgado
item.category: Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Thomas Cristofoletti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students in Angkor Chey, Cambodia, learning about the Khmer Rouge last month. A bus with access to a digital archive from the period is visiting schools across the country.

item.title: Wild Boars Are Wreaking Havoc in Scotland’s Countryside
item.description: Local residents say the animals are roaming the roads and hills around the lake, tearing up lawns and terrorizing sheep.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Sanderson and Grant Clark, unseen, retrieving a boar they shot near Loch Ness, in Scotland.

item.title: Knife Attack in Germany Kills at Least 3 at Solingen Festival
item.description: The attack took place in Solingen during a celebration of the 650th anniversary of the city’s founding. Eight people were wounded.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze

item.title: Why Mpox Vaccines Aren’t Flowing to Africans in Desperate Need
item.description: Drugmakers have supplies ready to ship that are necessary to stop a potential pandemic. But W.H.O. regulations have slowed access.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A health worker prepared a dose of the mpox vaccine at a medical center in Paris. The vaccine is widely available in the West but not in Africa.

item.title: Israel Presses for Gaza Border Presence as Part of Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Mediators in truce negotiations, including the C.I.A. director and President Biden’s Middle East envoy, are seeking a summit next week to keep the struggling talks alive.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near the Israeli-Gazan border on Friday.

item.title: Sudan’s Military Spurns Cease-Fire Talks in Switzerland
item.description: American-led mediators secured famine relief for needy areas. But with Sudan’s military failing to attend, a cease-fire was far out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Cease-fire talks for Sudan were convened by the U.S. envoy to Sudan, Tom Perriello, center. He appeared at a closing news conference with Sibylle Obrist, left, the head of the Swiss delegation, and Ali bin Hassan Jafar, the head of the Saudi delegation.

item.title: U.S. Tightens Technology Controls to Target Russian War Machine
item.description: The Biden administration announced new penalties on shell companies and suppliers that were feeding Russia’s war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: 135 Bonham Strand in Hong Kong. The office was the place of registration for companies that funneled millions of restricted chips and sensors to military technology companies in Russia, a New York Times investigation found.

item.title: Lucie Castets Wants to Be France’s Prime Minister but Needs Emmanuel Macron’s Backing
item.description: Lucie Castets, a relatively obscure bureaucrat, is the left’s choice to be prime minister. Just one person stands in her way: the president.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Lucie Castets is the New Popular Front’s candidate for prime minister of France. She has been doing something political analysts say they’ve never seen: campaigning for the job.
